<p></P>
<p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><A name="page_1"></A> </font></p>
<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr>
    <td width="10" bgcolor="#0066CC">&nbsp;</td>
    <td width="140" valign="top" bgcolor="#0066CC"> <p><font color="#FFFFFF" size="3" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><br>
        Letter to<br>
        Stockholders<br>
        <br>
        <br>
        <br>
        <br>
        Notice of 2003<br>
        Annual Meeting<br>
        and Proxy<br>
        Statement<br>
        <br>
        <br>
        </font><font color="#FFFFFF" size="3" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><br>
        <br>
        2002 Annual<br>
        Report to<br>
        Stockholders<br>
        <br>
        <br>
        <br>
        <br>
        </font><font color="#FFFFFF" size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<img src="whitebullet.jpg" width="5" height="5">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management&#146;s<br>
        &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Discussion and<br>
        &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Analysis<br>
        <br>
        <br>
        <br>
        <br>
        </font><font color="#FFFFFF" size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<img src="whitebullet.jpg" width="5" height="5">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Consolidated<br>
        &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Financial <br>
        &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Statements<br>
        <br>
        <br>
        <br>
        <br>
        <br>
        </font><font color="#FFFFFF" size="3" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Other
        Stockholder<br>
        Information<br>
        <br>
        <br>
        </font></p></td>
    <td width="16" valign="top">&nbsp;</td>
    <td valign="top"> <P align="center"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><br>
        <img src="logoc.jpg" width="320" height="39"> </font></P>
      <P align="center"> <font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=4>Proxy
        Statement and<br>
        2002 Annual Report to Stockholders</FONT></B> </font></P>
      <P align="right"> <FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">March
        26, 2003</FONT></p>
      <P align="left"> <FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">To Our
        Fellow Stockholders:</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">I am pleased to report
        that Hershey Foods, despite numerous distractions, exited 2002 as a fundamentally
        better business. We showed solid improvements in all areas: 1) profitability
        and returns were well above 2001 levels, 2) brand building and supply
        chain productivity gained momentum, and 3) the organization became and
        remains energized and unified around delivering superior shareholder value
        over the long term.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The 2001 assessment
        of Hershey&#146;s strengths and opportunities for improvement led to our
        new strategic direction. Our commitment to deliver balanced, profitable
        growth is built on four strategic initiatives:</FONT></p>
      <ul>
        <LI><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Drive profitable,
          organic sales growth;</FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><BR>
          </font></LI>
        <LI><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Profitably build
          rest-of-world scale;</FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><BR>
          </font></LI>
        <LI><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Create ongoing affordability
          through a low-cost, value-adding supply chain; and</FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><BR>
          </font></LI>
        <LI><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Build a streamlined,
          results-driven organization.</FONT></LI>
      </ul>
      <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>2002 Report
        Card</FONT></B> </font></P>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Consolidated net sales
        on a reported basis for 2002 were $4.12 billion, a decline of 0.4 percent.
        Net income for the year, including one-time charges, was $403.6 million
        or $2.93 per share-diluted, an increase of 95 percent. On a comparable
        basis, Hershey achieved strong financial results from ongoing operations
        in 2002:</FONT></p>
      <ul>
        <LI><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Comparable net sales
          of $4.11 billion increased by 0.3 percent;</FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><BR>
          </font></LI>
        <LI><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Earnings before
          interest and taxes of $749.5 million increased by 9.2 percent;</FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><BR>
          </font></LI>
        <LI><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Net income of $436.0
          million increased by 11.4 percent;</FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><BR>
          </font></LI>
        <LI><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Earnings per share-diluted
          of $3.17 increased by 11.6 percent; and</FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><BR>
          </font></LI>
        <LI><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Economic return
          on invested capital increased from 16.3 percent to 16.9 percent.</FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><BR>
          </font></LI>
      </ul>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">One-time items in
        2002 included cumulative pre-tax realignment charges of $34.0 million,
        or $.16 per share-diluted, and pre-tax expenses of $17.2 million, or $.08
        per share-diluted, related to the exploration of the sale of the company.
        One-time items in 2001 included the pre-tax charge of $278.4 million,
        or $1.25 per share-diluted, related to realignment initiatives; the gain
        on the sale of the </FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><I><FONT size=2>Luden&#146;s
        </FONT></I><FONT size=2>business, and the amortization of goodwill.</FONT></font></p></td></tr>
</table>
<hr noshade align="left" width="600" size=5>
<P align="center"> <font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><PAGE></font></p>
<p></P>
<font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><A name="page_2"></A> </font>
<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr>
    <td><p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>Profitable,
        Organic Growth</FONT></B> </font></P>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Hershey&#146;s leadership
        position within the U.S. confectionery market is a clear source of competitive
        advantage. In 2002, we focused our marketing and selling resources in
        four areas representing profitable growth opportunities.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">First, scale brands
        continued to offer business upside. Hershey&#146;s leading brands, which
        account for nearly 60 percent of our retail sales, had increased consumer
        takeaway of better than six percent, gaining market share. This growth
        was driven by value-added new items (Limited Edition </FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><I><FONT size=2>Hershey&#146;s
        Kisses </FONT></I><FONT size=2>chocolates, <I>Reese&#146;s FastBreak </I>candy
        bars, <I>Ice Breakers </I>mints and gum, and Limited Edition <I>Kit Kat
        </I>wafer bars), powerful advertising and improved retail execution.</FONT></font></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Our second area of
        focus was &#147;instant consumables&#148;&#151;convenient, on-the-go confectionery
        loose bars and individual packages of gum and mints. These items match
        up well against competitive snack products and provide a great source
        of incremental sales and market share growth across all retail channels.
        In 2002, &#147;instant consumables&#148; had a four-percent increase in
        retail takeaway.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Convenience stores
        represented the third area of emphasis. Hershey historically has been
        underrepresented in this important market segment. However, we made significant
        progress in 2002. Thanks to a combination of new products, better programming
        and targeted support at store level, Hershey&#146;s takeaway in convenience
        stores increased by nine percent, with a resulting market share gain.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The chocolate business
        was our fourth key driver during the year. It&#146;s the largest, most
        profitable segment of the U.S. confectionery business and, during 2002,
        was one of the most competitive as well. Despite this increased activity,
        Hershey maintained its overall share by increasing consumption three percent.
        Mints also did well during the year, with Hershey increasing its share
        of this attractive segment.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Two areas where results
        must improve are non-chocolate and gum. In non-chocolate, brands such
        as </FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><I><FONT size=2>Payday
        </FONT></I><FONT size=2>candy bar and <I>Jolly Rancher </I>candy did not
        perform at the required level. In the gum business, the <I>Ice Breakers
        </I>franchise and the total gum business performed well in convenience
        stores. However, total gum sales suffered across all remaining retail
        outlets. These areas will receive increased attention during 2003.</FONT></font></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The most notable enabler
        to our business-building efforts was the improved use of information.
        Integrated Business Intelligence (IBI) is Hershey&#146;s platform for
        assessing marketplace performance, identifying customer and consumer needs,
        and ensuring a disciplined approach to resource allocation. Good progress
        is being made as we build these capabilities.</FONT></p>
      <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>Rest of World</FONT></B>
        </font></P>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Results for our non-U.S.
        business, which accounts for a very small percentage of total sales, fell
        below expectations in 2002. Net sales were flat for the year and operating
        margins declined. Operations in Canada and Brazil had a very difficult
        year. In addition, our export business in South America was soft due to
        adverse economic conditions. The one bright spot was Hershey Mexico which
        delivered solid sales and profitability.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Going forward, we
        believe that Hershey brands can be successful outside the United States.
        We&#146;ve experienced good growth on the </FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><I><FONT size=2>Kisses
        </FONT></I><FONT size=2>and <I>Hershey </I>franchises in selected international
        markets. Nonetheless, the competitive marketplace is very challenging,
        and the lack of an adequate infrastructure in key global markets will
        restrict this growth in the near term. Several strategic alternatives
        to address the long-term opportunities currently are under review as we
        look to invest resources proportionally with the potential growth prospects.</FONT></font></p>
      <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>Supply Chain
        Performance</FONT></B> </font></P>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Hershey Foods has
        a cost-effective and flexible supply chain. This competitive advantage
        produced a significant increase in gross margins for 2002, +1.3 percentage
        points to 38.0 percent. While raw material savings were a positive factor,
        broad supply chain initiatives contributed to the total productivity gains.
        Product line rationalization, realignment of our manufacturing and distribution</FONT></p>
      <P align="center"> <FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">ii</FONT></p>
      <HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=5></td></tr>
</table>
<p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><PAGE></font></p>
<p></P>
<font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><A name="page_3"></A></font>
<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr>
    <td><p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">facilities, and disciplined
        general and administrative cost control throughout the company played
        key roles. Of special note is the strong improvement achieved within our
        logistics area over the past two years, delivering better customer service
        at a lower cost.</FONT></p>
      <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>Organizational
        Effectiveness</FONT></B> </font></P>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Of equal importance
        to our brand building and supply chain initiatives was the progress made
        on organizational development. I continue to be impressed with the commitment,
        positive attitude and teamwork exhibited by Hershey employees.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The beginning of 2002
        saw the majority of those taking the Early Retirement Program (ERP) leave
        the company. The ERP not only reduced expenses, but also provided significant
        career opportunities and enhancements for many employees. More than 400
        promotions occurred throughout the company, a streamlined management group
        assumed broader leadership responsibilities, and we began to better address
        employee communications and performance expectations.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Hershey experienced
        a six-week work stoppage at the Hershey and West Hershey plants during
        the second quarter of 2002. While no organization wants to experience
        such a disruption to its business or its employees&#146; lives, the rest
        of our company stepped up to help get us through this difficult period.
        Once the strike was resolved, we quickly returned to the business at hand,
        producing the best chocolate and confectionery products in the marketplace.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">We&#146;ve retained
        the Gallup organization over the past two years to conduct a survey of
        employee engagement across the entire company. Despite all that occurred
        in 2002, our results improved in comparison to 2001. Employees believe
        in the future of Hershey Foods and now have a much better understanding
        of the company&#146;s strategy. Importantly, the survey helped us identify
        key improvement opportunities across nearly 600 distinct work teams, opportunities
        which were turned into action plans and pursued by these teams throughout
        the year.</FONT></p>
      <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>Management
        and Board Changes</FONT></B> </font></P>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Several key management
        changes took place during 2002. On November 13, 2002, Milton T. Matthews,
        Vice President and Chief Customer Officer, announced his intention to
        retire in mid-2004. Milt is the consummate team player. His devotion to
        Hershey&#146;s brands, customers and people across the organization has
        been unequaled throughout his 30-year career with the company. Milt has
        built and nurtured a premiere confectionery selling organization that
        clearly is respected throughout the food industry.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">David J. West, formerly
        Senior Vice President, Business Planning and Development, was named Senior
        Vice President, Sales, effective December 1, 2002. Dave brings a combination
        of superior strategic insight and a &#147;get-it-done&#148; mindset to
        his new position. His broad experience in snacks, and the integral role
        he&#146;s played in developing Hershey&#146;s strategy, will help ensure
        delivery of our profitable growth objectives in a challenging marketplace
        environment.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Dennis N. Eshleman,
        formerly Vice President, Brand Integration, was promoted to Vice President,
        Strategy and Innovation, succeeding Dave West, effective December 1, 2002.
        He joins the Hershey Executive Team in this position. Throughout his 20-year
        career at Hershey, Dennis has demonstrated sound strategic insight and
        a commitment to winning. These qualities will serve the company well as
        he focuses on driving innovation across the entire business system and
        fostering company-wide strategic growth initiatives.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Jay F. Carr, Vice
        President, International, retired effective January 1, 2003, after 32
        years of outstanding service in many areas of the company. His previous
        positions include Vice President, Marketing for Hershey Chocolate USA;
        President, Hershey International; and President, Hershey Pasta and Grocery
        Group.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Succeeding Jay is
        Burton H. Snyder, formerly Senior Vice President-Public Affairs, General
        Counsel and Secretary, who assumed the position of General Counsel, Secretary
        and Senior Vice President, International, effective December 1, 2002.
        In taking on the international function, Burt combines broad company experience
        and a strong understanding of Hershey&#146;s international business.</FONT></p>
      <P align="center"> <FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">iii</FONT></p>
      <HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=5></td></tr>
</table>
<p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><PAGE></font></p>
<p></P>
<font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><A name="page_4"></A></font>
<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr>
    <td><p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Marcella K. Arline,
        formerly Senior Vice President, Human Resources, was named Senior Vice
        President, Human Resources and Corporate Affairs, effective December 1,
        2002. In this expanded position, Marcella assumes additional responsibility
        for Hershey&#146;s public affairs function. Her many years of corporate
        and operating experience, combined with her overall responsibility for
        Hershey&#146;s organizational effectiveness, will ensure strong support
        and coordination of the Company&#146;s internal and external communications
        efforts. </FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">John M. Pietruski,
        a Director since 1987, will retire from the Board in April 2003. He has
        served as Chairman of the Committee on Directors and Corporate Governance
        and as a member of the Compensation and Executive Organization Committee
        and the Executive Committee. Hershey Foods has benefited greatly from
        Jack&#146;s vast experience, discerning questions, and solid advice over
        the last 16 years. We thank him for his dedicated service to the company.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">J. Robert Hillier
        resigned from the company&#146;s Board of Directors effective December
        31, 2002. He had served on the Committee on Directors and Corporate Governance
        and the Compensation and Executive Organization Committee. The company
        has benefited from Bob&#146;s considerable knowledge and he has our sincere
        appreciation.</FONT></p>
      <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>Corporate
        Governance</FONT></B> </font></P>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Corporate governance
        received a heightened degree of focus from the Board of Directors and
        management in 2002. The Board has adopted all appropriate actions to ensure
        full compliance both with the listing standards of the New York Stock
        Exchange and provisions of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act as regulations are finalized
        and implemented. We established a Disclosure Committee comprised of senior
        corporate officers and chaired by the Chief Accounting Officer. This committee
        is charged with ensuring the appropriate process is in place and followed
        for all quarterly and annual financial filings. The committee reports
        directly to me, as Chief Executive Officer, and to our Chief Financial
        Officer. The committee also reports to the Audit Committee of the Board.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Over the past couple
        of years, the news accounts of corporate wrongdoing have been pervasive.
        The issue, more often than not, seems to involve a breakdown in individual
        accountability and integrity. I&#146;m convinced that &#147;corporate
        ethics&#148; cannot be legislated. Integrity and accountability begin
        and end with the individual. Your Board of Directors and Hershey management
        understand the role we play in setting the proper &#147;tone at the top.&#148;
        Investors, suppliers, customers and consumers must have complete confidence
        that Hershey always will operate with the highest legal, ethical and moral
        standards possible &#151; no exceptions, ever.</FONT></p>
      <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>The Sale
        Process</FONT></B> </font></P>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The year&#146;s review
        would not be complete without mentioning the &#147;sale process.&#148;
        In early 2002, Hershey Trust Company informed the Board of Directors of
        Hershey Foods that the Trust intended to explore means of diversifying
        its investments, including a sale of the company. This process ended six
        months later when the Trust rejected all offers. The demands of the sale
        process truly showed the strong character and determination of Hershey
        employees.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">We, at Hershey Foods,
        have eight core values to which we aspire: Openness and Candor, Teamwork,
        Integrity, Personal Leadership, Accountability, Passion for Winning, Inclusion,
        and Learning and Growing. Never were these values more tested or more
        evident than in 2002. I was so very proud of our company and our employees
        during this most difficult time. I&#146;m convinced that we have emerged
        a much stronger company and have benefited from this experience.</FONT></p>
      <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>Looking Ahead</FONT></B>
        </font></P>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Hershey Foods is a
        strong company with solid fundamentals. Our market-leading brands are
        known the world over and enjoy a leadership position in the largest confectionery
        market. Our strategic agenda is gaining traction, particularly in the
        key focus areas highlighted above. We&#146;ve seen a strong response to
        the marketing and selling efforts of our major brands as well as significant
        gains in productivity and cost control.</FONT></p>
      <P align="center"> <FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">iv</FONT></p>
      <HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=5></td></tr>
</table>
<p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><PAGE></font></p>
<p></P>
<font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><A name="page_5"></A></font>
<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr>
    <td><p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">As we look ahead,
        accelerating profitable top-line growth is our number-one priority. There
        are two components to deliver against this priority. First, we must increase
        Hershey&#146;s leadership position in the U.S. confectionery market. To
        this end, we have programs in place that capitalize on the strength within
        our brand equities and build upon 2002&#146;s success.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Second, we must leverage
        our core competencies in the broader snack market. Targeted adjacent segments
        offer incremental growth opportunities as consumers select from a broader
        array of snacks. We are intent on satisfying these needs. The marketplace
        is changing rapidly, and we will evolve our portfolio of brands and products
        to capitalize on these new opportunities.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">There are further margin
        expansion opportunities across the supply chain that will enable sustained
        investment in our growth initiatives. Whether it&#146;s through product
        line rationalization, increased manufacturing efficiency, further gains
        in the logistics area, or holding the line on general and administrative
        expenses, Hershey&#146;s cost profile can and will improve.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The company&#146;s
        cocoa costs will increase in 2004 as a result of recent price increases
        in the world cocoa market. These raw material cost increases will be offset
        through a combination of price increases and/or product weight changes,
        improved sales mix and additional efficiencies company-wide. We fully
        intend to achieve our long-term goals for growth and profitability through
        these measures.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">We&#146;ll continue
        to leverage the considerable financial strengths of Hershey Foods. Our
        cash flow generation has improved, as has our asset management. In mid-December
        2002, the Board of Directors authorized a $500 million share repurchase
        program that we intend to complete in 2003 or early 2004. The stock dividend
        was increased for the 28th consecutive year in August 2002, and we intend
        to continue to increase dividends as we build our business. Ongoing increases
        in cash flow provide flexibility for investing in our brands and business
        capabilities. Acquisitions and additional stock buy-backs are two potential
        areas that will receive the appropriate consideration.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">In summary, 2002 truly
        was a &#147;year of years.&#148; Despite numerous challenges, Hershey
        Foods delivered solid performance across numerous fronts. Our strategic
        agenda is sound and showing good promise. We understand the barriers to
        growth and will continue to work hard to unlock the immense potential
        of our company. Most important, it is a privilege for me to work with
        so many loyal, dedicated employees who share a common set of values and
        commitment to building our brands, building our people and rewarding our
        shareholders.</FONT></p>
      <p></P></td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td>&nbsp;</td>
  </tr>
</table>
<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">

      Board, President<br>
      and Chief Executive Officer</FONT></td></tr>
</table>

  <tr>
    <td><br>

        Harbor Statement on page A-22 for information about factors which could
        cause future results to differ materially from forward-looking statements,
        expectations and assumptions expressed or implied in this letter to stockholders
        or elsewhere in this publication.</I> </font></P>
      <P align="center"> <FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">v</FONT></p>
      <HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=5></td></tr>

<font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><PAGE></font>
<p></P>
<font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><A name="page_6"></A></font>

  <tr>
    <td><P align="center"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=4>2003
        Annual Meeting of Stockholders</FONT></B> </font></P>
      <UL>
        <LI><FONT face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">2:00 p.m., April 22, 2003
          (doors open at 12:30 p.m.)<BR>
          </FONT></LI>
        <LI><FONT face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The Hershey Lodge &amp;
          Convention Center, West Chocolate Avenue and University Drive<BR>
          </FONT></LI>
        <LI><FONT face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Map on back cover<BR>
          </FONT></LI>
        <LI><FONT face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Registered stockholders
          should bring Admission Ticket from top half of proxy card for admission
          to the Annual Meeting<BR>
          </FONT></LI>
        <LI><FONT face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">If voting by Internet,
          Admission Ticket will be forwarded to you<BR>
          </FONT></LI>
        <LI><FONT face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">If your shares are held
          by a broker, bank or other nominee, obtain a letter from broker, bank
          or nominee, or bring your most recent account statement showing ownership
          of Hershey stock as of February 27, 2003, to gain admission to the Annual
          Meeting and to receive HERSHEY&#146;S CHOCOLATE WORLD discount and product
          sample<BR>
          </FONT></LI>
        <LI><FONT face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">HERSHEY&#146;S CHOCOLATE
          WORLD visitors center will provide refreshments, a product sample and
          25% discount on selected items from 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.<BR>
          </FONT></LI>
        <LI><FONT face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">To receive product sample
          and 25% discount, present Admission Ticket, letter from broker, bank
          or nominee, or account statement described above<BR>
          </FONT></LI>
        <LI><FONT face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Live audio of the Annual
          Meeting will be webcast and available online in the Investor Relations
          area of www.hersheys.com<BR>
          </FONT></LI>
      </UL>
      <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B>Annual Meeting Security</B>
        </font></P>
      <p><FONT face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Security measures will be
        in place at the Annual Meeting for the safety of attendees. Metal detectors
        similar to those used in airports will be located at the entrance to the
        meeting room. Stockholders are strongly encouraged not to carry items
        such as handbags and packages to the meeting as all such items will be
        inspected. Photo identification will be required to gain admittance. Sharp
        objects, such as pocketknives and scissors, cameras and recording devices
        will not be permitted inside the meeting room.</FONT></p>
      <P align="center"> <FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">vi</FONT></p>
      <HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=5></td></tr>

  <TR bgcolor="#EEEEEE">
    <TD width="947"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><a href="#page_a1">APPENDIX
      A</a></FONT></TD>
    <TD width=78 nowrap>&nbsp;</TD></tr>
  <TR>
    <TD width="947"><a href="#page_a2"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">ANNUAL
      REPORT TO STOCKHOLDERS</FONT></a></TD>
    <TD width=78 align="right" nowrap><a href="#page_a2"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">A-1</FONT></a></TD></tr>
  <TR bgcolor="#EEEEEE">
    <TD width="947"><a href="#page_a2"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Management&#146;s
      Discussion and Analysis</FONT></a></TD>

<p></P>
<font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><A name="page_9"></A> </font>
<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr>
    <td><hr size="5" noshade>
      <P align="center">&nbsp;</P>
      <P align="center">&nbsp;</P>
      <P align="center">&nbsp;</P>
      <P align="center">&nbsp;</P>
      <P align="center">&nbsp;</P>
      <P align="center">&nbsp;</P>
      <P align="center"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=5>Notice
        of Annual Meeting<br>
        <br>
        and<br>
        <br>
        Proxy Statement</FONT></B></font></P>
      <P align="center">&nbsp;</P>
      <P align="center">&nbsp;</P>
      <P align="center">&nbsp;</P>
      <P align="center">&nbsp;</P>
      <P align="center">&nbsp;</P>
      <P align="center">&nbsp;</P>
      <P align="center">&nbsp;</P>

<P align="center">&nbsp;</p>
<PAGE>
<p></P>
<font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><A name="page_11"></A></font>
<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr>
    <td><P align="center"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">&nbsp;<img src="logob.jpg" width="319" height="38"></font></P>
      <hr width="100" size="1" noshade> <div align="center"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>NOTICE
        OF ANNUAL MEETING OF STOCKHOLDERS<br>
        <br>
        on<br>
        <br>
        April 22, 2003<br>
        </FONT></B> </font>
        <hr width="100" size="1" noshade>
      </div>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The Annual Meeting
        of Stockholders of HERSHEY FOODS CORPORATION will be held at 2:00 p.m.
        on April 22, 2003 at The Hershey Lodge &amp; Convention Center, West Chocolate
        Avenue and University Drive, Hershey, Pennsylvania 17033 for the following
        purposes:</FONT></p></td></tr>
</table>
<br>
<table width="600" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
  <TR>
    <TD valign="top" width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD valign="top" width="5%"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">(1)</FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">&nbsp;</font></TD>
    <td valign="top"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">To elect
      nine directors;</FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><BR>
      &nbsp;</font></TD></tr>
  <tr>
    <td valign="top" width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td valign="top" width="5%"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">(2)</FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">&nbsp;</font></TD>
    <td valign="top"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">To approve
      the appointment of KPMG LLP as the Corporation&#146;s independent auditors
      for 2003;</FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><BR>
      &nbsp;</font></TD></tr>
  <tr>
    <td valign="top" width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td valign="top" width="5%"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">(3)</FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">&nbsp;</font></TD>
    <td valign="top"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">To consider
      and act upon a stockholder proposal to expense stock options, if presented
      at the meeting; and</FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><BR>
      &nbsp;</font></TD></tr>
  <tr>
    <td valign="top" width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td valign="top" width="5%"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">(4)</FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">&nbsp;</font></TD>
    <td valign="top"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">To transact
      such other business as may be brought properly before the meeting and any
      and all adjournments thereof.</FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><BR>
      &nbsp;</font></TD></tr>
  <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">In
      accordance with the By-Laws and action of the Board of Directors, stockholders
      of record at the close of business on February 27, 2003 will be entitled
      to notice of, and to vote at, the meeting and any and all adjournments thereof.<br>
&nbsp;</FONT></td></tr>
</TABLE>
<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr>
    <td width="50%">&nbsp;</td>
    <td width="50%"><p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">By order
        of the Board of Directors,</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Burton H. Snyder<br>
        </FONT><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">General Counsel,
        Secretary and<br>
        Senior Vice President, International<br>
&nbsp;</FONT></p></td></tr>
  <tr>
    <td colspan="2"><p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">March
        26, 2003</FONT></p>
      <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>Please follow
        the instructions on the enclosed proxy card for voting by Internet or
        by telephone whether or not you plan to attend the meeting in person;
        or if you prefer, kindly mark, sign and date the enclosed proxy card and
        return it promptly in the enclosed, postage-paid envelope.</FONT></B>
        </font></P>
      <HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=5></td></tr>
</table>
<p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><PAGE></font></p>
<p></P>
<font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><A name="page_12"></A></font>
<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr>
    <td><hr align="center" width="200" size="1" noshade> <div align="center"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>P
        R O X Y&nbsp;&nbsp;S T A T E M E N T</FONT></B> </font> </div>
      <hr align="center" width="200" size="1" noshade> <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">This
        Proxy Statement is furnished in connection with the solicitation of proxies
        by the Board of Directors of HERSHEY FOODS CORPORATION, a Delaware corporation
        (the &#147;Corporation&#148; or &#147;Hershey Foods&#148;), for use at
        the Annual Meeting of Stockholders (&#147;Annual Meeting&#148;) which
        will be held at 2:00 p.m., Tuesday, April 22, 2003 at The Hershey Lodge
        &amp; Convention Center, West Chocolate Avenue and University Drive, Hershey,
        Pennsylvania, and at any and all adjournments of that meeting. This Proxy
        Statement and the enclosed proxy card are being sent to stockholders on
        or about March 26, 2003. The Corporation&#146;s principal executive offices
        are located at 100 Crystal A Drive, Hershey, Pennsylvania 17033-0810.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Shares represented
        by properly voted proxies received by the Corporation at or prior to the
        Annual Meeting will be voted according to the instructions indicated by
        such proxies. Unless contrary instructions are given, the persons named
        on the proxy card intend to vote the shares so represented </FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>FOR
        </FONT></B><FONT size=2>the election of the nominees for director named
        in this Proxy Statement, <B>FOR </B>approval of the appointment of KPMG
        LLP as the Corporation&#146;s independent auditors for 2003 and <B>AGAINST
        </B>the stockholder proposal to expense stock options, if presented at
        the meeting. As to any other business which may properly come before the
        Annual Meeting, the persons named on the proxy card will vote according
        to their best judgment.</FONT></font></p>
      <P align="center"> <font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>Proposal
        No. 1 &#151; ELECTION OF DIRECTORS</FONT></B> </font></P>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Nine directors are
        to be elected at the Annual Meeting, each to serve until the next Annual
        Meeting and until his or her successor shall have been elected and qualified.
        With the exception of Mmes. Harriet Edelman and Marie J. Toulantis, each
        of the nominees named in the following pages is currently a member of
        the Board of Directors (the &#147;Board&#148;). John M. Pietruski, currently
        a director of the Corporation, will retire from the Board as of the Annual
        Meeting on April 22, 2003. J. Robert Hillier, formerly a director of the
        Corporation, resigned from the Board effective December 31, 2002 in anticipation
        of his resignation from the Board of Directors of Hershey Trust Company
        and the Board of Managers of Milton Hershey School on January 6, 2003.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Pursuant to the Corporation&#146;s
        Restated Certificate of Incorporation, as amended (&#147;Certificate&#148;),
        and By-Laws, one-sixth of the directors, which equates presently to two
        directors, is to be elected by the holders of the Corporation&#146;s Common
        Stock, one dollar par value (&#147;Common Stock&#148;), voting separately
        as a class. The nominees receiving the greatest number of votes of the
        holders of the Common Stock voting separately as a class will be elected.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Mmes. Harriet Edelman
        and Marie J. Toulantis have been nominated by the Board for the positions
        to be elected by the holders of the Common Stock voting separately as
        a class. The remaining seven individuals listed have been nominated by
        the Board for the seven positions to be elected by the holders of the
        Common Stock and the Corporation&#146;s Class B Common Stock, one dollar
        par value (&#147;Class B Stock&#148;), voting together without regard
        to class. The seven nominees receiving the greatest number of votes of
        the holders of the Common Stock and Class B Stock voting together will
        be elected. In case any of the nominees should become unavailable for
        election for any reason not presently known or contemplated, the persons
        named on the proxy card will have discretionary authority to vote pursuant
        to the proxy for a substitute.</FONT></p>
      <P align="center"> <FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">2</FONT></p>
      <HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=5></td></tr>
</table>
<font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><PAGE></font>
<p></P>
<font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><A name="page_13"></A> </font>
<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr>
    <td><img src="bosciasig.jpg" width="82" height="122" hspace="10" align="left">
      <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>JON A. BOSCIA</FONT></B><FONT size=2>,
        age 50, is Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Lincoln National Corporation,
        Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, a leading financial services company. He was
        elected Chairman of the Board of Lincoln National Corporation in March
        2001 and has been Chief Executive Officer since July 1998. From January
        1998 to March 2001, Mr. Boscia held the office of President. Prior to
        1998, Mr. Boscia held several positions within Lincoln Financial Group,
        the marketing name for Lincoln National Corporation and its affiliates.
        A Hershey Foods director since 2001, he is a member of the Audit Committee
        and the Committee on Directors and Corporate Governance.</FONT></font></p>
      <p>&nbsp;</P>
      <hr align="center" width="200" size="1" noshade> <p>&nbsp;</p>
      <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b><font size=2><img src="campbellsig.jpg" width="82" height="121" hspace="10" align="left"></font></b></font><FONT size=2>ROBERT
        H. CAMPBELL</FONT></B><FONT size=2>, age 65, retired in 2000 as Chairman
        of the Board and Chief Executive Officer, Sunoco, Inc., Philadelphia,
        Pennsylvania, a petroleum refiner and marketer. He had been Chief Executive
        Officer since 1991, Chairman of the Board since 1992 and a director of
        Sunoco, Inc. since 1988. He is a director of CIGNA Corporation. A Hershey
        Foods director since 1995, he is a member of the Audit Committee and the
        Compensation and Executive Organization Committee.</FONT></font></p>
      <p>&nbsp;</p>
      <p>&nbsp;</p>
      <hr align="center" width="200" size="1" noshade> <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2><img src="coughlansig.jpg" width="82" height="122" hspace="10" align="left">GARY
        P. COUGHLAN</FONT></B><FONT size=2>, age 59, retired in 2001 as Senior
        Vice President, Finance and Chief Financial Officer of Abbott Laboratories,
        Inc., Abbott Park, Illinois, a diversified international healthcare company.
        He had held that position since May 1990. He is a director of Arthur J.
        Gallagher &amp; Co. and General Binding Corporation. A Hershey Foods director
        since 2001, he is a member of the Audit Committee and the Compensation
        and Executive Organization Committee.</FONT></font></P>
      <p></p>
      <p>&nbsp;</p>
      <p>&nbsp;</P>
      <hr align="center" width="200" size="1" noshade> <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2><img src="edelmansig.jpg" width="82" height="122" hspace="10" align="left">HARRIET
        EDELMAN</FONT></B><FONT size=2>, age 47, is Senior Vice President and
        Chief Information Officer of Avon Products, Inc., New York, New York,
        the world&#146;s leading seller of beauty and related products. She was
        elected to that position in January 2000. She was formerly Senior Vice
        President, Global Operations from June 1998 to January 2000 and Group
        Vice President, North American Supply Chain from January 1996 to June
        1998. She is a director of Blair Corporation. She has been nominated as
        a new director for election by the holders of the Common Stock voting
        separately as a class.</FONT></font></p>
      <P align="center">&nbsp;</p>
      <P align="center"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><br>
        3</FONT></p>
      <HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=5></td></tr>

<font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><PAGE></font>
<p></P>
<font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><A name="page_14"></A></font>
<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr>
    <td>
      <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><b><font size=2><img src="hillsig.jpg" width="82" height="122" hspace="10" align="left"></font></b></font></B></font><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>BONNIE
        G. HILL</FONT></B><FONT size=2>, age 61, is President of B. Hill Enterprises,
        LLC, Los Angeles, California, a consulting company, and Chief Operating
        Officer of Icon Blue, Inc., Los Angeles, California, a brand marketing
        company. Previously she was President and Chief Executive Officer of The
        Times Mirror Foundation; and Senior Vice President, Communications and
        Public Affairs, <I>The Los Angeles Times</I>, a subsidiary of Tribune
        Company. She is a director of AK Steel Holding Corporation, Albertson&#146;s,
        Inc., ChoicePoint, Inc., The Home Depot, Inc., and National Grid Transco
        plc. A Hershey Foods director since 1993, she is a member of the Audit
        Committee and the Compensation and Executive Organization Committee.</FONT></font></p>
      <p>&nbsp;</p>
      <hr align="center" width="200" size="1" noshade> <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2><img src="jamisonsig.jpg" width="81" height="121" hspace="10" align="left">JOHN
        C. JAMISON</FONT></B><FONT size=2>, age 68, is President, Williamsburg
        Community Trust, a community foundation, Williamsburg, Virginia. Prior
        to 2003, he was Chairman of Mallardee Associates, a privately-held corporate
        financial services firm, Williamsburg, Virginia. A Hershey Foods director
        since 1974, he chairs the Audit Committee and is a member of the Executive
        Committee.</FONT></font></p>
      <p>&nbsp;</p>
      <p>&nbsp;</P>
      <hr align="center" width="200" size="1" noshade> <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2><img src="lennypic.jpg" width="83" height="122" hspace="10" align="left">RICHARD
        H. LENNY</FONT></B><FONT size=2>, age 51, was elected Chairman of the
        Board, President and Chief Executive Officer of Hershey Foods Corporation
        effective January 1, 2002. From March 2001 to December 2001, he was President
        and Chief Executive Officer of the Corporation. From January 2001 until
        March 2001, he was Group Vice President of Kraft Foods, Inc. and President
        of its Nabisco Biscuit and Snack business. From February 1998 to December
        2000, he was President, Nabisco Biscuit Company; and from January 1997
        to February 1998, he was President, Pillsbury North America. He is a director
        of Sunoco, Inc. A Hershey Foods director since 2001, he chairs the Executive
        Committee and is a member of the Committee on Directors and Corporate
        Governance until his term expires on April 22, 2003.</FONT></font></p>
      <p>&nbsp;</p>
      <hr align="center" width="200" size="1" noshade> <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2><img src="mcdonaldpic.jpg" width="82" height="123" hspace="10" align="left">MACKEY
        J. McDONALD</FONT></B><FONT size=2>, age 56, is Chairman of the Board,
        Chief Executive Officer and President of VF Corporation, Greensboro, North
        Carolina, an international apparel company. He was elected Chairman of
        the Board of VF Corporation in 1998. He has been Chief Executive Officer
        since 1996 and President since 1993. He is a director of Wachovia Corporation
        and Tyco International Ltd. A Hershey Foods director since 1996, he chairs
        the Compensation and Executive Organization Committee and is a member
        of the Executive Committee.</FONT></font></p>
      <P align="center">&nbsp;</p>
      <P align="center">&nbsp;</P>
      <P align="center"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">4</FONT></p>
      <HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=5></td></tr>
</table>
<font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><PAGE></font>
<p></P>
<font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><A name="page_15"></A></font>
<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr>
    <td>
      <p><img src="toulantispic.jpg" width="82" height="122" hspace="10" align="left"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>MARIE
        J. TOULANTIS, </FONT></B><FONT size=2>age 48, is Chief Executive Officer
        of Barnes &amp; Noble.com, New York, New York, an online retailer of books,
        music and DVDs. She was elected to that position in February 2002. From
        May 2001 to February 2002, Ms. Toulantis held the office of President
        and Chief Operating Officer; and from May 1999 to May 2001 held the office
        of Chief Financial Officer. From March 1999 to May 1999, Ms. Toulantis
        was Chief Financial Officer of Barnes &amp; Noble, Inc., the world&#146;s
        largest bookseller, operating over 900 Barnes &amp; Noble and B. Dalton
        stores nationwide, and from July 1997 until March 1999, was that company&#146;s
        Executive Vice President, Finance. She has been nominated as a new director
        for election by the holders of the Common Stock voting separately as a
        class.</FONT></font></p>

      <p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>The Board
        of Directors recommends a vote FOR the director nominees listed above,
        and proxies that are returned will be so voted unless otherwise instructed.</FONT></B>
        </font></P>
      <P align="center"> <font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>BOARD
        COMMITTEES</FONT></B> </font></P>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The Board has four
        standing committees: the Audit Committee, the Committee on Directors and
        Corporate Governance, the Compensation and Executive Organization Committee,
        and the Executive Committee. In addition to the four standing committees,
        the Board from time to time establishes committees of limited duration
        for special purposes.</FONT></p></td></tr>
</table>
<br>
<table width="600" border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0>
  <TR>
    <TD width="50%"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>Audit
      Committee</FONT></B></font></TD>
    <TD width=50% align="right"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">8
      meetings in 2002</FONT></td></tr>
  <TR>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD></tr>
  <TR>
    <TD width="50%"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Members:</FONT></TD>
    <TD width=50%><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">John C. Jamison
      (Chair)</FONT></TD></tr>
  <TR>
    <TD width="50%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width=50%><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Jon A. Boscia</FONT></TD></tr>
  <TR>
    <TD width="50%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width=50%><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Robert H.
      Campbell</FONT></TD></tr>
  <TR>
    <TD width="50%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width=50%><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Gary P. Coughlan</FONT></TD></tr>
  <TR>
    <TD width="50%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width=50%><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Bonnie G.
      Hill</FONT></TD></tr>
  <TR>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD></tr>
  <TR>
    <TD width="50%"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Responsibilities:</FONT></TD>
    <TD width=50%><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Assists the
      full Board:</FONT></TD></tr>
  <TR>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD></tr>
  <TR>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">In its oversight
        of the Corporation&#146;s accounting and financial reporting principles
        and policies and internal controls and procedures;</FONT></P>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">In its oversight of
        the Corporation&#146;s financial statements and the independent audit
        thereof;</FONT></P>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">In selecting (or nominating
        the independent auditors to be proposed for stockholder approval), evaluating
        and, where deemed appropriate, replacing the independent auditors; and</FONT></P>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">In evaluating the
        independence of the independent auditors.</FONT></p></td></tr>
</TABLE>

        on Directors and Corporate Governance will consider nominees recommended
        by stockholders. Such recommendations must comply with the procedures
        for nomination set forth in the section entitled &#147;Stockholder Proposals
        and Nominations,&#148; beginning on page 28.</FONT></P>

    <td width="50%"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Responsibilities:</FONT></td>
    <td width="50%"> <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Establishes
        the salaries of the Corporation&#146;s elected officers;</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Grants performance
        stock units, stock options and other rights under the Corporation&#146;s
        Key Employee Incentive Plan, as amended (&#147;Incentive Plan&#148;);</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Establishes target-award
        levels and makes awards under the Annual Incentive Program and the Long-Term
        Incentive Program of the Incentive Plan;</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Administers the Incentive
        Plan, the Employee Benefits Protection Plans and the Supplemental Executive
        Retirement Plan;</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Monitors compensation
        arrangements for management employees for consistency with corporate objectives
        and stockholders&#146; interests;</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Reviews the executive
        organization of the Corporation; and</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Monitors the development
        of personnel available to fill key management positions as part of the
        succession planning process.</FONT></p></td></tr>

<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr>
    <td><P align="center"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>DIRECTORS&#146;
        ATTENDANCE</FONT></B></font></P>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">There were six regular
        meetings and seven special meetings of the Board of Directors during 2002.
        No director attended less than 83% of the sum of the total number of meetings
        of the Board and the total number of meetings held by all committees of
        the Board on which he or she served during 2002. Average attendance for
        all of these meetings equaled 95%.</FONT></p>
      <P align="center"> <font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>DIRECTORS&#146;
        COMPENSATION</FONT></B> </font></P></td></tr>
</table>
<table width="600" border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0>
  <TR>
    <TD colspan="4">&nbsp;</TD></tr>
  <TR>
    <TD colspan="4"><HR noshade size=1></TD></tr>
  <TR bgcolor="#EEEEEE">
    <TD><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Annual Retainer</FONT></TD>
    <TD width=5 align="center"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">$</FONT></TD>
    <TD width=36 align="right"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">55,000</FONT></TD>
    <TD width=10>&nbsp;</TD></tr>
  <TR>
    <TD colspan="4"><HR noshade size=1></TD></tr>
  <TR>
    <TD><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Annual Restricted Stock
      Unit Grant</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="center" width=5><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">$</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right" width=36><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">40,000</FONT></TD>
    <TD width=10>&nbsp;</TD></tr>
  <TR>
    <TD colspan="4"><HR noshade size=1></TD></tr>
  <TR bgcolor="#EEEEEE">
    <TD><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Annual Retainer for
      Committee Chairs</FONT></TD>
    <TD width=5 align="center"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">$</FONT></TD>
    <TD width=36 align="right"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">5,000</FONT></TD>
    <TD width=10>&nbsp;</TD></tr>
  <TR>
    <TD colspan="4"><HR noshade size=1></TD></tr>
</TABLE>
<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr>
    <td>&nbsp;</td></tr>
  <tr>
    <td><p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The Directors&#146;
        Compensation Plan is designed to attract and retain qualified non-employee
        directors and to align the interests of non-employee directors with those
        of the stockholders by paying a portion of their compensation in units
        representing shares of Common Stock. Directors who are employees of the
        Corporation receive no remuneration for their services as directors.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Restricted stock units
        (&#147;RSUs&#148;) are granted quarterly on the first day of January,
        April, July and October on the basis of the number of shares of Common
        Stock, valued at the average closing price on the New York Stock Exchange
        of the Common Stock on the last three trading days preceding the grant,
        equal to $10,000. While the value of the annual RSU grant is targeted
        at $40,000, the actual value of the grant may be higher or lower depending
        upon the performance of the Common Stock following the grant dates. A
        director&#146;s RSUs will vest and be distributed upon his or her retirement
        from the Board.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Directors may elect
        to receive all or a portion of their retainer in cash or Common Stock,
        although committee chair fees are paid only in cash. A director may defer
        receipt of the retainer and committee chair fees until his or her retirement
        from the Board.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">All directors are
        reimbursed for reasonable travel and other out-of-pocket expenses incurred
        in connection with attendance at Board and committee meetings and for
        minor incidental expenses incurred in connection with performance of directors&#146;
        services. In addition, directors are provided with travel accident insurance
        while traveling on the Corporation&#146;s business, receive the same discounts
        as employees on the purchase of the Corporation&#146;s products and are
        eligible to participate in the Corporation&#146;s Higher Education Gift
        Matching Program.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The Corporation maintains
        a Directors&#146; Charitable Award Program for individuals who became
        directors prior to December 31, 1996. This program is a self-funded life
        insurance program on eligible directors and funds charitable donations
        by the Corporation to educational institutions designated by those directors.
        The amount of the donation varies according to the director&#146;s length
        of service as a director, up to a maximum donation of $1 million after
        five years of service. With the exception of Jon A. Boscia, Gary P. Coughlan,
        and Richard H. Lenny, who became directors after December 31, 1996, all
        current directors and fourteen retired directors participate in the program.
        The amount of the charitable donation per current participating director
        is $1 million.</FONT></p>
      <P align="center"> <FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">7</FONT></p>
      <HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=5></td></tr>
</table>
<p><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><PAGE></font></p>
<p></P>
<font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><A name="page_18"></A></font>
<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr>
    <td><P align="center"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>AUDIT
        COMMITTEE REPORT</FONT></B> </font></P>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The role of the Audit
        Committee of the Board of Directors is to assist the Board in its oversight
        of the Corporation&#146;s financial reporting process. The Board has determined
        that all members of the Audit Committee are &#147;independent,&#148; as
        required by applicable listing standards of the New York Stock Exchange.
        The Audit Committee operates pursuant to a Charter that was last amended
        and restated by the Board on February 7, 2001. As set forth in the Charter,
        management of the Corporation is responsible for the preparation, presentation
        and integrity of the Corporation&#146;s financial statements, the Corporation&#146;s
        accounting and financial reporting principles, and internal controls designed
        to assure compliance with accounting standards and applicable laws and
        regulations. The independent auditors are responsible for auditing the
        Corporation&#146;s financial statements and expressing an opinion as to
        their conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the
        United States.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">In the performance
        of its oversight function, the Audit Committee has considered and discussed
        the audited financial statements with management and the independent auditors.
        The Audit Committee has also discussed with the independent auditors the
        matters required to be discussed by Statement on Auditing Standards No.
        61, </FONT><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><I><FONT size=2>Communication
        with Audit Committees</FONT></I><FONT size=2>, as currently in effect.
        Finally, the Audit Committee has received the written disclosures and
        the letter from the independent auditors required by Independence Standards
        Board Standard No. 1, <I>Independence Discussions with Audit Committees</I>,
        as currently in effect, has discussed with the independent auditors the
        auditors&#146; independence from the Corporation and its management, and
        has considered whether the provision of non-audit services to the Corporation
        by the independent auditors is compatible with maintaining the auditors&#146;
        independence.</FONT></font></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The members of the
        Audit Committee are not professionally engaged in the practice of auditing
        or accounting, are not employed by the Corporation for accounting, financial
        management or internal control purposes, and are not experts in the fields
        of accounting or auditing, including with respect to auditor independence.
        Members of the Audit Committee rely, without independent verification,
        on the information provided to them and on the representations made by
        management and the independent auditors. Accordingly, the Audit Committee&#146;s
        oversight does not provide an independent basis to determine that management
        has maintained appropriate accounting and financial reporting principles
        and policies or internal controls and procedures designed to assure compliance
        with accounting standards and applicable laws and regulations. Furthermore,
        the Audit Committee&#146;s considerations and discussions referred to
        above do not assure that the audit of the Corporation&#146;s financial
        statements has been carried out in accordance with auditing standards
        generally accepted in the United States, that the financial statements
        are presented in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted
        in the United States or that the Corporation&#146;s auditors are in fact
        &#147;independent.&#148;</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Based upon the reports
        and discussions described in this report, and subject to the limitations
        on the role and responsibilities of the Audit Committee referred to above
        and in the Charter, the Audit Committee recommended to the Board that
        the audited financial statements be included in the Corporation&#146;s
        Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2002 to be
        filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.</FONT></p>
      <P align="center"> <FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">SUBMITTED
        BY THE AUDIT COMMITTEE OF THE CORPORATION&#146;S<br>
        </FONT><font size="2" face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">BOARD OF DIRECTORS</font></P></td></tr>
</table>
<br>
<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr align="center">
    <td><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">John C. Jamison, Chair</FONT></td>
    <td>&nbsp;</td>
    <td><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Jon A. Boscia</FONT></td>
    <td>&nbsp;</td>
    <td><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Robert H. Campbell</FONT></td></tr>
  <tr align="center">
    <td>&nbsp;</td>
    <td><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Gary P. Coughlan</FONT></td>
    <td>&nbsp;</td>
    <td><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Bonnie G. Hill</FONT></td>
    <td>&nbsp;</td></tr>

    <td>&nbsp;</td>

  <tr align="center">
    <td colspan="5"><P align="center"><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">8</FONT></p>
      <HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=5></td></tr>

<P align="center"> <font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><PAGE></font></p>
<p></P>
<font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><A name="page_19"></A></font>
<table width="600" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
  <tr>
    <td><P align="center"><font face="Times New Roman, Times, serif"><B><FONT size=2>VOTING
        SECURITIES</FONT></B> </font></P>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The Corporation has
        shares of two classes of stock outstanding, Common Stock and Class B Stock.
        At the close of business on February 27, 2003, the record date for the
        Annual Meeting, there were outstanding 102,132,277 shares of Common Stock
        and 30,422,308 shares of Class B Stock, all of which are entitled to be
        voted. Holders of record of the Corporation&#146;s Common Stock on February
        27, 2003 will be entitled to cast one vote for each share held, and holders
        of record of the Class B Stock on February 27, 2003 will be entitled to
        cast ten votes for each share held. The Common Stock is entitled to cash
        dividends 10% higher than those declared on the Class B Stock.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">According to the Corporation&#146;s
        By-Laws, the presence in person or by proxy of the holders of a majority
        of the votes entitled to be cast of the outstanding Common Stock and Class
        B Stock, respectively, shall constitute quorums for matters to be voted
        on separately by the holders of the Common Stock voting separately as
        a class and the holders of the Class B Stock voting separately as a class.
        The presence in person or by proxy of the holders of a majority of the
        votes entitled to be cast by the combined outstanding shares of the Common
        Stock and the Class B Stock shall constitute a quorum for matters to be
        voted on without regard to class.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">The vote required
        for approval of any matter which may be the subject of a vote of the stockholders
        is provided for in the Corporation&#146;s Certificate and By-Laws. The
        specific vote requirements for the proposals being submitted to a stockholder
        vote at this year&#146;s Annual Meeting are set forth under the description
        of each proposal in this Proxy Statement.</FONT></p>
      <p><FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">Abstentions and broker
        non-votes (defined below) are counted for the purpose of determining whether
        a quorum is present at the Annual Meeting. For the purpose of determining
        whether a proposal (except for the election of directors) has received
        a majority vote, abstentions will be included in the vote totals with
        the result that an abstention will have the same effect as a negative
        vote. In instances where brokers are prohibited from exercising discretionary
        authority for beneficial owners who have not returned a proxy (&#147;broker
        non-votes&#148;), those shares will not be included in the vote totals
        and, therefore, will have no effect on the vote.</FONT></p>
      <P align="center"> <FONT size=2 face="Times New Roman, Times, serif">9</FONT></p>
      <HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=5></td></tr>
</table>

      of February 27, 2003, stockholders noted in the following table owned the
      indicated number of shares of the Corporation&#146;s Common Stock (including
      Common Stock equivalent shares) and Class B Stock. Unless otherwise indicated
      in a footnote, the individuals listed below have voting and investment power
      over the shares indicated. The voting and investment power over the shares
      held by the Milton Hershey School Trust and Hershey Trust Company are as
      indicated in the section entitled &#147;Description of the Milton Hershey
      School Trust and Hershey Trust Company.&#148;</FONT></td></tr>
